Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phrases to communicate with others at school, appropriate to their relationships
Elaboration: Understanding the concepts of ‘adult’ and ‘child’ and how these influence how we communicate and behave with different people

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phrases to communicate with others at school, appropriate to their relationships
Elaboration: Participating in simple conversation role-play with peers and known adults; for example, practising what they might say when greeting the school principal or entering a staff member’s office, and greeting a friend when they get to school or leave at the end of the day

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phrases to communicate with others at school, appropriate to their relationships
Elaboration: Learning to use language according to the relationship between people; for example, using sentence strips or visual supports to structure appropriate sentence starters, and modelling conversations by knocking on a teacher’s or the principal’s office door and asking a scripted sentence, such as ‘Can I collect your recycling?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phrases to communicate preferences, likes and dislikes
Elaboration: Recognising and practising how preferences might be communicated in speech or by using visual symbols, voice-output devices, signed language or gestures; for example, using the sentence starter ‘I like …’ and choosing an image to identify what they like

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phrases to communicate preferences, likes and dislikes
Elaboration: Requesting an object, for example by selecting and sequencing symbols to show ‘Can I have a drink please?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise that texts can take different forms
Elaboration: Comparing different ways that information can be presented, for example on a screen or device, in a book, or on a sign or poster

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise that texts can take different forms
Elaboration: Identifying different forms and purposes of texts at school, for example signs, labels, schedules, and procedural texts (including recipes) or posters with visual sequences (such as instructions for washing hands)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the front and back cover of a book, left to right directionality and return sweep of print; recognise that words are separate to pictures
Elaboration: Participating in activities that familiarise them with concepts about print; for example, when handed a book with the back cover face up, turning it and ‘reading’ from the start, or orienting the book and pointing to the side that is correct when asked ‘Can you show me the back cover?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the front and back cover of a book, left to right directionality and return sweep of print; recognise that words are separate to pictures
Elaboration: Demonstrating left to right directionality; for example, pointing to the words in a book and moving their finger from left to right or following sentences with their eyes to identify that print is what we read

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Construct and use phrases to express ideas
Elaboration: Combining words to express an idea using structured sentence prompts combining 2 ‘wh’ elements, for example ‘The (who) is (what)?’ (‘The dog is eating.’, ‘The dog is barking.’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Construct and use phrases to express ideas
Elaboration: Using phrases to contribute to class-created texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use phrases to describe objects and actions
Elaboration: Communicating about something that happened during their day, for example ‘I read a book.’ or ‘We did writing.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use phrases to describe objects and actions
Elaboration: Participating in show-and-tell and describing an object or action, for example ‘I cooked a cake.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use phrases to describe objects and actions
Elaboration: Recalling relevant information from a text that has been read to describe something a character did, for example ‘Fred is asleep.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify the contribution of images and words to meaning in stories and informative texts
Elaboration: Pointing to print while reading a page with both print and pictures, distinguishing words from pictures

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify the contribution of images and words to meaning in stories and informative texts
Elaboration: Requesting that an adult write words next to a picture they have drawn or selected

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify the contribution of images and words to meaning in stories and informative texts
Elaboration: Identifying the main topic of a story or informative text using their preferred communication modality

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use learnt vocabulary related to everyday experiences, personal interests and topics taught at school
Elaboration: Recognising frequently used words or gestures in familiar environments; for example, responding to visual or verbal instructions, retrieving the correct image or indicating a simple decodable word from a selection to contribute to a class text

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Use learnt vocabulary related to everyday experiences, personal interests and topics taught at school
Elaboration: Using vocabulary that is appropriate and relevant to specialist classes, for example ‘going to the gym’ for Physical Education (PE) or ‘We used paint.’ after an art class

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify that spaces between words indicate a new word
Elaboration: Using strategies such as finger spacing or using the space bar to indicate a new word

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify that spaces between words indicate a new word
Elaboration: Recognising the space between words when reading by briefly pausing between words

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify that spaces between words indicate a new word
Elaboration: Moving their finger from word to word, indicating individual words are separate units

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify experiences that are similar to their own by engaging with literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Viewing stories by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander storytellers from print, visual, digital and multimodal sources and identifying a connection to their own experiences, such as seeing a kangaroo with a joey in its pouch or camping in a bush setting

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify experiences that are similar to their own by engaging with literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Making connections between their own experiences and those of characters within a story, for example where people live, their mode of transportation and the weather

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Share feelings on the events and characters depicted in a text
Elaboration: Answering questions using their preferred communication modality about their feelings in response to a text during shared reading, for example ‘How would that make you feel?’

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Share feelings on the events and characters depicted in a text
Elaboration: Using symbols, drawing or beginning forms of writing to communicate responses to stories; for example, drawing or choosing a sad face to indicate they feel sad after reading a sad story

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify a setting, character and event in a text
Elaboration: Incorporating vocabulary such as ‘first, next, then’ and ‘beginning, middle, end’, for example in anchor charts, or first/then or first/next/then visual supports to map the key events in a shared text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify a setting, character and event in a text
Elaboration: Sequencing information; for example, ordering a set of sentence strips or using graphic organisers to record the events in a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify a setting, character and event in a text
Elaboration: Drawing or contributing ideas to a class description of a character in a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Replicate the rhythms of familiar chants, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Accompanying rhythm and sound patterns using body percussion, such as tapping knees and clapping hands

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Replicate the rhythms of familiar chants, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Listening to, then repeating a sound pattern such as ‘clap, clap, stomp’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Replicate the rhythms of familiar chants, rhymes and songs
Elaboration: Chanting known, repeated phrases from a familiar book at the appropriate time

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell an event from a preferred or known text through role-play, performance, images, drawing or writing
Elaboration: Role-playing characters or events from familiar stories using props

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell an event from a preferred or known text through role-play, performance, images, drawing or writing
Elaboration: Sequencing pictures, words or drawings to retell a story

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Retell an event from a preferred or known text through role-play, performance, images, drawing or writing
Elaboration: Using a variety of words and phrases to communicate understanding about a book; for example, retelling a part of a story with props such as a felt board or puppets

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their preferred communication modality to initiate and sustain an interaction with others
Elaboration: Participating in small-group activities and initiating a discussion; for example, choosing a photo or the name of a peer to participate in a ‘turn and talk’ or ask a question of

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their preferred communication modality to initiate and sustain an interaction with others
Elaboration: Inviting classmates to play a turn-taking game with them

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their preferred communication modality to initiate and sustain an interaction with others
Elaboration: Knocking on the door and entering another classroom to relay a message and bring back a response

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phrases to retell a story or event to peers
Elaboration: Contributing to established routines, such as ‘morning message’ or show-and-tell, by identifying and sharing ideas with the class

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phrases to retell a story or event to peers
Elaboration: Presenting a personally written text to the class

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Blend and segment a small number of one-syllable words
Elaboration: Beginning to engage in syllable and blending activities

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Blend and segment a small number of one-syllable words
Elaboration: Segmenting words into individual sounds, for example by finger tapping, moving counters or playing segmenting games

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Blend and segment a small number of one-syllable words
Elaboration: Dividing a spoken word into its component sounds through segmentation activities; for example, segmenting the individual phonemes in ‘cat’ (/k/ /a/ /t/)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use beginning knowledge of letters and sounds to read some consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words
Elaboration: Reproducing sounds in isolation; for example, using a voice-output device or producing speech

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use beginning knowledge of letters and sounds to read some consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words
Elaboration: Developing skills that support the articulation and pronunciation of sounds and words accurately

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use beginning knowledge of letters and sounds to read some consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words
Elaboration: Reading decodable words and simple decodable texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise familiar words and identify them in environmental print
Elaboration: Identifying symbols and words within the classroom or wider school environment; for example, removing a symbol accompanied by a word from the daily schedule once an activity is finished

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise familiar words and identify them in environmental print
Elaboration: Recognising signs, symbols and words in the community, for example stop sign, toilet sign and pedestrian crossing sign

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise familiar words and identify them in environmental print
Elaboration: Being exposed to irregular high-frequency words in text, such as ‘was’, ‘are’ and ‘the’, which have irregular sound–letter correspondences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise familiar words and identify them in environmental print
Elaboration: Being introduced to new vocabulary associated with learning activities discussing the meaning of new words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Apply developing phonemic knowledge to decode words in short sentences or simple decodable texts
Elaboration: Listening to and identifying individual sounds in spoken words, for example by playing rhyming games, or sound matching or isolation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Apply developing phonemic knowledge to decode words in short sentences or simple decodable texts
Elaboration: Identifying the relationship between letters and their corresponding sounds, for example through alphabet songs and chants

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Apply developing phonemic knowledge to decode words in short sentences or simple decodable texts
Elaboration: Putting individual sounds together to form simple consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words, for example by word building with letters (magnetic or letter tiles)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as connecting, predicting and questioning to understand texts listened to and/or viewed
Elaboration: Sequencing ideas to retell familiar stories in response to questions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as connecting, predicting and questioning to understand texts listened to and/or viewed
Elaboration: Predicting what might happen in a text, based on the title and cover

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as connecting, predicting and questioning to understand texts listened to and/or viewed
Elaboration: Using prompts to ask questions and seek further information related to texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short texts to record an idea and/or events
Elaboration: Creating a drawing or selecting an image and writing an accompanying sentence to record an idea

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short texts to record an idea and/or events
Elaboration: Using a sentence stem to create a short text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create short texts to record an idea and/or events
Elaboration: Constructing or co-constructing and following procedural texts, such as individual schedules, recipes and task lists

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Participate in shared editing of a class text, identifying some capital letters and applying spacing between words
Elaboration: Responding to questions about capital letters, for example ‘Does small m or capital M go first in your name?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Participate in shared editing of a class text, identifying some capital letters and applying spacing between words
Elaboration: Co-creating and editing a class text and applying strategies to identify some capital letters

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to form letters
Elaboration: Practising letter formation using a range of writing tools and/or activities; for example, writing letters in shaving cream using their finger

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to form letters
Elaboration: Creating text using letters (or letter-like symbols) or using alternative writing tools

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to form letters
Elaboration: Including the forms of some letters and numbers in their drawing or writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use tools to form letters
Elaboration: Writing one or more letters in their name; for example, signing in when arriving at school by writing their name
